They are one of the most successful clubs in Swiss football, having won the [[Swiss Super League]] 14 times, the third most for any Swiss club. They were most successful in the late 1960s and 1970s, winning the title a total of seven times between 1967 and 1980. The 1980s saw hard times for Basel as they had an absence from European competition for many years and they were relegated in 1987. In the 2000s Basel returned to the top of Swiss football; winning their first title for 22 years in 2002 and another five titles in 2004, 2005, 2008, 2010, and 2011. They have competed in [[UEFA|European competition]] every season since 1999â2000. In the 2001â02 season the club reached the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup]] final, losing to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], in the 2002/03 season they qualified for the Second Group Stage of the [[UEFA Champions League]] and in the 2005/06 season they reached the Quarter-Finals of the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]]. They have been in the Champions League more times than any other Swiss club (a total of 4 times) and are the first and only Swiss club to have ever qualified directly for the Champions League group-stages. == History == {{Recentism|date=July 2009}} {{Main|History of FC Basel}} ===The Early Years=== {{Expand section|date=September 2008}} FC Basel was started by an advertisement on the 12 November 1893 that appeared in the Basler national newspaper requesting that a football team be formed and that anyone that wished to join should meet up the next Wednesday at 8:15. So, on the 15th of November 1893, FC Basel was born in the city of [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]]. One of the early [[Captain (association football)|club captains]] was [[Joan Gamper]], who later founded [[FC Barcelona]] in [[La Liga|Spain]]. FC Basel did not have much of an early footballing success; it took them 40 years to win their first trophy, winning the [[Swiss Cup]] in 1933 when they defeated arch-rivals and reigning cup-holders [[Grasshopper-Club ZÃ¼rich]] 4â3, in what is now considered to be one of the best cup finals in Swiss football history. They also won the cup in 1947 when they beat [[FC Lausanne-Sport|Lausanne Sports]], who also finished runners-up the previous year, 3â0. Basel won their first [[Swiss Super League|league title]] [[1952/1953 football season in Switzerland|in 1953]], with club legend [[RenÃ© Bader]] as manager. They finished three points above [[BSC Young Boys]]. ===Rise and Fall=== {{Expand section|date=September 2008}} Basel won their first trophy of the new decade in 1963; with [[Czechoslovakia]]n manager [[JiÅÃ­ Sobotka|Georges Sobotka]] at the helm, Basel stormed to [[Swiss Cup]] glory by overcoming [[Grasshopper-Club ZÃ¼rich]] 2â0 in the final. But, FCB (which is pronounced "Eff Cee Bee" in [[Swiss German]]) came to prominence in the late 1960s under the management of [[Helmut Benthaus]] and with quality players such as [[RenÃ© Hasler]], [[Ottmar Hitzfeld]] and [[Karl Odermatt]]. Benthaus' first league win as Basel manager was in [[1966/1967 football season in Switzerland|1967]], finishing a single point above [[FC ZÃ¼rich]]. A cup final victory over [[FC Lausanne-Sport|Lausanne Sports]] also came later in the season. This led to Basel qualifying to play in the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]], for the first time, [[European Cup 1967â68|in 1968]]. Basel were knocked out of the tournament in the First Round, however, by [[Danish 1st Division|Danish side]] [[Akademisk Boldklub]]. Basel's next league win came [[1968/1969 football season in Switzerland|in 1969]], when they once again finished just one point above the runners-up, who this time were [[FC Lausanne-Sport|Lausanne Sports]]. This meant that Basel could embark on another European adventure, but they, once again, failed to overcome the first hurdle, who were [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] of [[Scottish Premier League|Scotland]]. In the [[1969/1970 football season in Switzerland|1969/70 season]], Basel won the league by one point over [[FC Lausanne-Sport|Lausanne Sports]], once again. The [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] was a little kinder to Basel [[European Cup 1970â71|in 1970]], as they reached the Second Round, losing to [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]], after defeating [[Russian Premier League|Soviets]] [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] in the First Round. Basel did not retain their title [[1970/1971 football season in Switzerland|the next season]] despite finishing with the same amount of points as the winners, [[Grasshopper-Club ZÃ¼rich]], who won it on head-to-head. After a trophy-less season, Basel then won two league titles in-a-row, [[1971/1972 football season in Switzerland|in 1972]] and [[1972/1973 football season in Switzerland|'73]]. They also won the [[Swiss League Cup|League Cup]] in 1973. In Europe, Basel failed to impress, once again, [[European Cup 1972â73|in 1972]], as they were sent crashing out at the first stage by [[Hungarian National Championship I|Hungary's]] [[Ãjpest FC|Ãjpesti DÃ³zsa SC]] but in the [[European Cup 1973â74|1973/74 season]] they excelled; eliminating [[Ãrvalsdeild|Icelanders]] [[KnattspyrnufÃ©lagiÃ° Fram|Fram ReykjavÃ­k]] and [[Club Brugge K.V.|Club Brugge]] of [[Belgian First Division|Belgium]], before narrowly exiting in the Quarter-Finals to [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] 5â6 on aggregate. Despite Basel's improvement on the [[UEFA|European stage]], they did not retain the league for another four years, but they did manage to lift the [[Swiss Cup]] in 1975, beating [[FC Winterthur]] 2â1 [[extra time|after extra time]]. Basel's long awaited title-win came [[1976/1977 football season in Switzerland|in 1977]] as they triumphed over [[Servette FC]] in a playoff. This meant that Basel returned to play in the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] but they were defeated in the First Round, once more, by [[FC Wacker Innsbruck]] of [[Austrian Football Bundesliga|Austria]], after showing so much promise on their last European outing. After the success of the 1976/77 season, Basel endured two seasons of below-par performances and mid-table finishes until glory returned in [[1979/1980 football season in Switzerland|in 1980]], as Basel won the [[Swiss Super League|Nationalliga A]] title through the playoff. However, [[head coach|manager]] [[Helmut Benthaus]] left in 1982 and in the following seasons, Basel's final league positions started to drop until their relegation into the [[Swiss Challenge League|Nationalliga B]] [[1987/1988 football season in Switzerland|in 1988]]. Several managers came and went at [[St. Jakob Stadium]] between then and when Basel finally returned to [[Swiss Super League|Nationalliga A]] [[1994/1995 football season in Switzerland|in 1994]], under [[Claude Andrey]]. Basel avoided relegation by three points in their first season back at the top-flight, but Andrey left and was replaced by [[Karl Engel]]. Engel led Basel to a fifth-place finish in [[1995/1996 football season in Switzerland|his first season in charge]] and a solid mid-table finish in [[1996/1997 football season in Switzerland|1997]], but he was sacked after a poor start to the [[1997/1998 football season in Switzerland|1997/98 campaign]], in which Basel finished second-bottom. [[JÃ¶rg Berger]] then took over, but lasted only a year in charge before [[Christian Gross]] came. Gross' appointment went hand-in-hand with the financial backing that had just been put into the club and it was not long until Basel returned to the top. ===Return of the Glory Days===

This was in protest at the kick off times being moved to accommodate a tennis tournament on the TV schedule.http://justcantbeatthat.com/2010/fc-luzern-1-1-fc-basel/ ===Rivalry=== The city of Basel and the city of [[ZÃ¼rich]] have a long-standing rivalry. In the past few seasons, the rivalry between FC ZÃ¼rich and Basel and has been fueled by FC ZÃ¼rich's league championship wins, which were won very narrowly over Basel. Supporters from both sides have caused trouble in the past years. The worst incident happened in May 2006. FC Basel had won the league in the 2003/04 and 2004/05 seasons and were set to make it three in a row if they won or drew against ZÃ¼rich at home on the last day of the 2005/06 season. But if ZÃ¼rich won, they would get the title. ZÃ¼rich took the lead after a late goal from [[Iulian Filipescu]] and consequently won the match and the league. The logo is worn in the centre of the shirt opposed to on the traditional left-hand side. Like the colours of FC Basel, the logo has a striking resemblance to that of [[FC Barcelona]] in [[Spain]]. There are theories that suggest that the founder of FC Barcelona, being at one time the captain of FC Basel, reincorporated the logo of FC Basel on to that of FC Barcelona. The resemblances seem clear, both logos seem to incorporate the shield design, as do most other clubs. But most notably is the FCB acronyms on both logos and the Red-Blue colours, outlined in gold. Also the football that lies on the left side of the FC Basel logo seems to be the exact shape, type and colour as that of the FC Barcelona Logo in the bottom centre.
